instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.TPS51125: What is TPS51125? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1278 model Macbooks.
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start
threads.message:
Hello,

an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> came in with minor water damage around <TRANSISTOR>Q9807</TRANSISTOR> area. 
green light OK
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.52v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> OK

Does not boot. What do I measure first?

Thank you

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start
threads.message: Shorted power pads? These do not auto power on. Checked resistance to GND on pp3V42?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start
threads.message: Thank you Duke! Shorting pads does nothing. Resistance to GND on pp3V42 is 0.311v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start
threads.message: That is not resistance that is a diode mode, need resistance.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start
threads.message: Sorry... Resistance to GND on pp3V42 is 21.10KOhm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start
threads.message: That may be a bit low but now 100% sure. Look carefully for corrosion around <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>, did anything get liquid around that? Battery charging?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start
threads.message: Battery is charging. <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> area is clean, minor corrosion on unconnected <RESISTOR>R5001</RESISTOR> pin 2.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start
threads.message: Checked all rails for shorts? Any corrosion around the <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP>? <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> doing anything when you press power button?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start
threads.message: Found short in <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> line, diode mode is 0.014v. Also <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_MCP</SIGNAL> is 0.015v. No corrosion around <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP>. <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> is going from 3.3v to almost 0 when shorting <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL> pads.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start
threads.message: Resistance to GND is the only way to check for real shorts. Diode mode measures a voltage drop, not quite the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_MCP</SIGNAL> resistance to GND is 24 Ohm

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light no start
threads.message: and that is no short. I would say either crap under the SMC or the MCP is dead.
